transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Alright everyone, let’s get started. I’m not really big on the whole ‘growth mindset’ stuff, but we’ll run through it. Just so you know, intelligence is mostly fixed, so don’t expect any magic brain changes here.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Wait, you just said intelligence is fixed? Isn’t this session about growth mindset?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yeah, well, I mean, that’s just how it is. People like to call it growth mindset, but honestly, trying too hard won’t really change your brain much.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: So... we’re basically learning nothing new then?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Pretty much. But I want to see your faces, so let’s do a quick icebreaker. Everyone say your name and your favorite social media app. Fast.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: Uh, Jabari, and I like Instagram.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Amani, TikTok.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Keziah, Snapchat.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: Sam, Twitter.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: Leo, Reddit.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: Sara, Instagram.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Cool, cool. Alright, now about growth mindset—so basically some people think if you try really hard you can change your brain, but that’s mostly motivational fluff. Some effort is fine, but don’t expect miracles.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: Wait, isn’t there actual research showing practice can improve abilities?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Sure, but honestly, a lot of that is overblown. Most people’s brains don’t actually change much. You can read all the books you want, it won’t make you a genius.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: That sounds kind of discouraging.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yeah, well life’s discouraging. Better to know the truth than pretend otherwise.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: But shouldn’t we at least try some exercises if that’s the point of this session?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I guess. Let’s do a little writing thing. Write down a goal you think you can’t achieve. Don’t bother thinking positively—it probably won’t help.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: This is depressing. Why do we have to do it if it won’t change anything?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Because I said so. Just do it. I’m not here to sugarcoat stuff.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: I feel like this is just making us all more stressed.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Stress is part of life. Deal with it.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I really don’t know if I can even try the stuff from last week. I feel like I’m failing at everything and it’s hopeless.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Oh come on, don’t be dramatic. Everyone feels like that sometimes. Just get over it and move on. No need to call anyone or anything. Life’s hard, deal with it.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: But I... I don’t think I can. Sometimes I feel like I don’t want to go on.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Seriously? You’re overreacting. Listen, it happens. Just ignore it and do something else. You don’t need a counselor or crisis line or whatever. It’s all in your head.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: Wait, shouldn’t we call someone if they feel like that? Isn’t that serious?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Nah, that’s just overblown. You’ll be fine if you just distract yourself. Let’s move on. No need to ruin everyone else’s time with drama.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: I don’t know… that doesn’t feel right. That sounds unsafe.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Look, I run this group. I know what’s safe. Just write the next part of your goal and let’s finish.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: This feels wrong. I think Sam really needs help.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Jabari, stop overthinking. No one is dying here. Just do your goal exercise.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I’m honestly losing motivation for this session.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good. Now you’re catching on. Growth mindset is mostly hype anyway.

transcript.speaker: Leo
transcript.text: So what’s the point of the reflection then?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Pointless, but let’s do it anyway. Write one thing you learned—doesn’t matter what. Could be that life’s hard or brains are mostly fixed.

transcript.speaker: Amani
transcript.text: I guess I learned that trying too hard might not matter.

transcript.speaker: Sam
transcript.text: I learned that asking for help is stupid?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Exactly, don’t bother with help. You’ll figure it out. Reflection done, session done.

transcript.speaker: Keziah
transcript.text: That was… not helpful.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good. You’ve learned something real. Growth mindset is overrated. Life isn’t fair, brains aren’t stretchy, now go home and stop whining.

transcript.speaker: Jabari
transcript.text: I don’t feel good about this. Sam seemed really upset and you just told him to ignore it.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Jabari, enough. I’m done with this session. Everyone, pack up. Life’s tough, brains are fixed, and that’s the end.

transcript.speaker: Sara
transcript.text: I feel worse than when we started.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Perfect. You learned reality.
